title: 107_s329
content: The Act may be cited as the "Peopling of America Theme Study Act" and includes findings and purposes. Congress finds that the migration, immigration, and settlement of the population of the United States, broadly termed the "peopling of America," is characterized by the movement of groups of people across boundaries and their interactions, with each group making unique contributions to American history, culture, art, and life. The diversity of the American population has contributed to the vitality of the United States in various aspects such as spiritual, intellectual, cultural, political, and economic. Embracing diversity has strengthened the national fabric and unified the country in its values, institutions, experiences, goals, and accomplishments. The National Park Service's thematic framework ensures the representation of the full diversity of American history and prehistory. The National Park Service's thematic framework aims to represent the diversity of American history and prehistory, emphasizing human population movement and change. Despite the 70,000 listings on the National Register of Historic Places, sites related to the exploration and settlement of the United States by various cultures are underrepresented. The Act aims to promote understanding of the contributions of diverse groups in shaping the United States. The Act aims to represent the diversity of American history by recognizing the contributions of various groups in shaping the United States and strengthening the National Park Service's ability to include underrepresented groups and events. The Act defines key terms such as "Secretary," "theme study," and "peopling of America." It also mandates a national historic landmark theme study on the peopling of America. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the peopling of America to identify key events and sites that shaped the culture and society of the United States. The study will recommend new national historic landmarks for designation. The theme study will include a list of appropriate sites for national historic landmark designation and encourage nominations to the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary will designate new national historic landmarks based on the study. Additionally, the theme study will identify sites within the National Park System for interpreting the peopling of America and recommend new sites for potential inclusion in the National Park. The Secretary will evaluate, designate new national historic landmarks, recommend sites for potential inclusion in the National Park System, and establish linkages based on the theme study for interpreting the peopling of America. The Secretary will establish linkages between regions, areas, trails, districts, communities, sites, buildings, structures, objects, organizations, societies, and cultures for interpreting the peopling of America. The Secretary will establish linkages to maximize opportunities for public education and research on the peopling of America, entering into cooperative arrangements to preserve key sites and using documentation for educational initiatives. The Secretary will implement cooperative programs to encourage the preservation and interpretation of the peopling of America through curriculum material, heritage tourism products, and oral history programs. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, professional associations, or other entities knowledgeable about the peopling of America to prepare the theme study, ensure its scholarly standards, and promote cooperative programs. Authorization of appropriations is provided to carry out this Act.
